title-group.article-title: Design of a single-DOF kinematic chain using hybrid GA-pattern search and sequential GA

article-meta.aff: 1Division of Mechanical Engineering, Northumbria University, Newcastle upon Tyne, UK

abstract.p: With the aim of obtaining an optimal design for a single-DoF kinematic chain with the function of morphing aerofoils, two search methods are developed. The assessment criteria arethe length of the linkage and the accuracy of mapping. While the former is taken as the objective of optimization, the latter is treated as a constraint. The accuracy in mapping is measured by the aerodynamic performance deviation, a parameter defined by combining the geometric deviation and a weighting function based on the distribution of pressure coefficient. The first search method is based on a genetic algorithm (GA) with an embedded pattern search algorithm. The aim of the pattern search is to reduce the number of failed attempts in generating feasible solutions for the initial population of the GA as well as repairing infeasible individuals produced by reproduction operators. In the second search method, the set of design variables is determined in two consecutive steps by employing a sequential GA. Results of five runs of each search method reveal that while the best solution was produced by the sequential GA search method, hybrid GA-pattern search yielded more consistent results with shorter lengths and better mapping precision in average.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p:
Adaptive or passive smart aerodynamic lifting surfaces, such as adaptive blades and smart wings, have received a significant amount of attention in the recent years [1–5]. These structures change their topologies, and hence their aerodynamic characteristics and performance, in response to the variation ofoperating conditions. Analysis, design, and testing of adaptive lifting surfaces are different from those of conventional lifting surfaces [1]. As illustrated in Fig. 1(a), aerodynamic analysis and design of conventional lifting surfaces can be carried out separately from their structural design as the designer does not need any information on the material and structural characteristics of the surface. Therefore, aerodynamic design and test of conventional wings or blades are decoupled from their structural design and test. Testing a solid wooden model of a wing in a wind tunnel is a traditional means to investigate the aerodynamic performance of a real hollow metal or composite wing. Fig. 1
Design–test iterations for: (a) conventional aerodynamic surfaces, (b) adaptive aerodynamic surfaces: aero-structure design and test, and (c) adaptive aerodynamic surfaces: using active structure in aerodynamic design test instead of testing the smart model

In contrary to conventional lifting surfaces, the aerodynamic and structural behaviour of adaptive lifting surfaces are strongly interconnected. In this case, the aerodynamic analysis and design cannot be carried out without having sufficient knowledge about the material properties and structural characteristics. Moreover, as illustrated in Fig. 1(b), the aerodynamic performance cannot be tested unless the surface is made from smart materials and the real structural behaviour (e.g. induced deformation) is taken into account. Figure 1(c) shows an alternative method of testing the aerodynamic performance of an adaptive lifting surface. This method is more cost-effective. In this method, a model with active structure is tested instead of an adaptive model. The active model mimics the adaptivity of the lifting surface by utilizing actuators. In contrast to a coupled aero-structure design and test (Fig. 1(b)), in which one adaptive model must be fabricated in each design–test iteration, the response of an active model can be easily controlled and altered for various operating scenarios. This makes the method of Fig. 1(c) an attractive means of evaluating the aerodynamic performance of adaptive aerodynamic surfaces. This study is focused on the design of such an active model with a morphing aerofoil and a controllable twist to be used as the test rig for the aerodynamic test of adaptive wings and blades.

sec.title: 2 DESIGN PROBLEM
sec.p:
In the design of the morphing aerofoil mechanism,the following requirements have been considered: The test rig should be capable of morphing both thin and thick aerofoils. It should be able to morph any initial aerofoil to any target aerofoil by minimum modifications. It should provide easy and precise control with minimum complexity and cost. Also, it should have enough rigidity at end positions to withstand the aerodynamic load. Figure 2 shows a single-DoF (degrees of freedom) kinematic chain providing the desired function of morphing an initial aerofoil to a target one. The function of this mechanism is to transfer N points of a given initial curve y1(x) to N points of a given target curve y2(x), in a given interval I=[0,c]. Link A1AN, the chord member, passes through the slider and is fixed. Slider is attached to the actuator. Points C are located on the slider. Horizontal movement of the slider changes the locations of points A2 to AN-1, leading to a change in the form of ysk. Fig. 2
Single-DOF kinematic chain for morphing aerofoils

This mechanism, due to its form, can be fabricated with required structural integrity to withstand aerodynamic loads. The number and size of the panels affect the accuracy of the mapping process as well as the total length of the linkage. This mechanism satisfies the above requirements more rigorously compared to multi-DoF mechanisms with either rigid or compliant members.

In contrary to the apparent simplicity of the problem of synthesizing a mechanism for mapping a curve y1(x) to a curve y2(x), in a given interval I=[0,c], here one has an optimal design problem with a variable and potentially large number of design variables. The set of design variables contains the number of precision points on curve y1(x), N, their x-coordinates, xAi, (i = 1 to N), and m design variables defining the mechanism. Parameterm itself depends on the number of precision points. Therefore, the total number of the variables that must be obtained through the optimization process is m(N)+N+1. Having N as a design variable makes the total number of design variables variable.

Having fixed the leading and trailing edge points, A1 and AN, also excluding the stroke of the slider fromthe set of design variables, two separate mechanisms can be independently designed to map the upper and the lower surfaces of the initial aerofoil to those of the target aerofoil. Synthesis of either ofthese mechanisms includes determination of 5(N-2)+1 unknowns (N,xA i,xB i,yB i,xC i,yC i), i∈{2,…,N-1}. Here, N is the number of precision points on the upper or lower surface of the blade/wing. Since the y-coordinates of points C are highlyconstrained within a narrow interval of (-a+δ1,+a-δ1), their variations will have minor effect on the design and therefore all of them are set initially to zero. This reduces the number of design variables involved in the optimization problem to 4(N-2)+1. Since only one independent constraint equation exists for each panel, letting x-coordinates of points A and x- and y-coordinates of points B as design variables, x-coordinates of points C are left to be determined using this constraint equation. The total number of independent design variables for the mechanism of Fig. 2 is therefore 3(N-2)+1.

Here, in the evaluation of design candidates, two criteria have been considered: (1) the total length of the linkage l, as a direct indication to the weight and complexity of the structure and therefore its cost, and (2) deviation of the aerodynamic performance of the mapped curve from that of the target aerofoil, ε. The aerodynamic performance deviation of the mapped curve from the target aerofoil is defined as (1) in which yct(x*) and ysk(x*) represent the contour and skeleton curves, respectively, x*=x/c the dimensionless x-coordinate, ∫01| yct(x*)-ysk(x*) | dx* the geometric deviation, and w(x*) the weighting function, transforming the geometric deviation into aerodynamic performance deviation. The weighting function w(x*) is defined as (2) where CP(x*) stands for the pressure coefficient distribution, |dCPdx*| the absolute value of the slope of CP curve, and |dCPdx*|min and |dCPdx*|max the minimum and maximum slopes, respectively. Having the pressure coefficient distribution, the slope of the curve, the maximum and minimum slopes, and the weighting function w(x*) can be easily found. Pressure coefficient depends on the flow kinematics (e.g. angle of attack), flow dynamic characteristics (e.g. Reynolds number), and the aerofoil geometry. Pressure coefficient distribution and therefore w(x*) vary as a result of a change in flow status (a change in the flow angle of attack and Reynolds number). However, in design optimization problem, it is assumed that w(x*) is constant and is calculated based on the CP(x*) distribution at the dominant operating angle of attack and Reynolds number. The aerodynamic performance deviation can be defined for both initial and target aerofoils. The deviation used in the optimization problem, hence, should be the maximum of these two values ɛ=max{ɛinitial,ɛtarget}.

This is a multi-objective optimization problem with the aerodynamic performance deviation, ε, and length of the mechanism, l, as the two contradicting objectives that need to be minimized. An accepted means of solving optimization problems of this kind is to convert them to single-objective problems by treating one objective as the constraint. Here, since a goal value for the aerodynamic performance deviation, ɛg, can be sensibly decided based on the required accuracy in the mapping process, the aerodynamic performance deviation is treated as a constraint. A feasible solution is now defined as a solution which satisfies constraints (4) to (9) as well as the imposed constraint on deviation (10)
The optimization problem can therefore be reformulated as (11)
subject to constraints (4) to (10).

In this study, two search methods have been developed and employed for solving the above optimization problem. In the first method, all design variables are determined in one step. Section 3 elaborates on a hybrid GA-pattern search developed for this purpose. In the second method, a two-step algorithm is employed. Section 4 describes the sequential genetic algorithm (GA) developed and employed to solve this problem. Results obtained by the two methods are compared in Section 5.

sec.title: 3 HYBRID GA-PATTERN SEARCH
sec.p: In conventional GAs, an initial population of designcandidates is randomly generated. A random selection of Xj={Nj,xA i,xB i,yB i} and solving for the x-coordinates of points C not necessarily yield a feasible solution, which satisfies all the constraints (4) to (10). In highly constrained problems, random generation of a decent-size initial population of feasible solutions can be very time consuming, making theconventional GAs inefficient or even impractical. In these cases, generating a feasible initial population is in fact a bottleneck with respect to the entire optimization process.

Figure 4 shows the average number of failed attempts to generate a correct mechanism against the number of panels in the mechanism. Here, the term correct mechanism refers to mechanisms satisfying constraints (4) to (9) only. It is evident that in order to produce mechanisms with high number of panels, significant computational effort is required, not to mention a correct mechanism is not necessarily feasible unless it satisfies constraint (10) too. Fig. 4
Average number of failed attempts in generating a correct mechanism

Since solutions with smaller aerodynamic performance deviations comprise a relatively large number of panels, the number of failed attempts in generating a feasible solution increases exponentially as the goal deviation (ɛg) decreases. Examining the effect of the value of the goal deviation on the number of failed attempts, it can be observed that for a goal deviation of ɛg=0.001, the average number of failed attempts is about 600, while this value increases significantly toabout 365 000 attempts forɛg=0.0006 (Fig. 5). In fact, a random generation of an initial population fails in practice when high precision in the mapping process (smallerɛg) is required. In order to overcome this problem, the initial population generation is facilitated by implementing a robust pattern search-based repair with the aim of reducing the average number of failed attempts. Fig. 5
Average number of failed attempts in generating a solution with ɛ≤ɛg

sec.title: 3.1 Initial population generation
sec.p: In the developed hybrid pattern search GA, rather than producing a chromosome Xj={Nj,xA i,xB i,yB i} randomly and then synthesizing the mechanism to findxC i, the chromosome is constructed step by step. At each step, the genes corresponding to one panel are selected and the corresponding xC i is determined. Each panel which violates constraint (8) is considered for repair. In the repair process, a pattern search around point B of the panel in the direction at which relocation of point B reduces the infeasibility is carried out. The objective of the pattern search is to reduce the distance between the point C of the panel and the edge of the slider towards locating C on the slider. The objective function for the pattern search is defined as (12)
This method, provided it exists within the pattern mesh, finds a new location for B which leads to a panel in which the calculated x-coordinate of point C does not violate constraint (8).
An initial mesh size Δ0=8δ1 is used. In each mesh-size reduction, we set Δk+1=0.5Δk is set leading to Δmin=δ1 after three-step size reductions.

Figure 5 shows the effect of the pattern search based repair procedure on the reduction of the number of failed attempts in producing an initial solution. It is evident that a significant reduction in the number of failed attempts can be achieved by implementing this repair process (e.g. 365 000 failed attempts is reduced to below 10 for ɛg=0.0006).

In a further step in facilitating the generation of the initial population, the constraint ɛ≤ɛg is treated as a constraint with dual soft/hard nature. That is, the departure of deviation ε beyond the goal value is tolerated to some extent (the constraint is treated as a soft constraint) and the objective is penalized for this departure. For higher departure values, this constraint is treated as a hard constraint and design candidates with high level of violations will be discarded. A solution which satisfies constraints (4) to (9) only but its deviation is between the goal value,ɛg, and the tolerated value ɛt (ɛg<ɛ≤ɛt) is considered as an ‘acceptable’ solution. Initial population contains both feasible and acceptable solutions, which satisfy constraints (4) to (9) and constraint (13) (13)

Solutions with ɛ>ɛt will be discarded.

sec.title: 3.2 Reproduction operators
sec.p: In the developed GA, due to the presence of a large number of design variables, a real number encoding is used. Using a real number encoding, each chromosome is made of 3(N-2)+1 genes corresponding to design variables (N,xA i,xB i,yB i). Here, since N is a design variable itself, the chromosomes of different solutions may have different lengths. Various methods of crossover have been proposed and successfully employed for GAs. Only few of them can be applied on variable-length chromosomes, where the lengths of the chromosome of the parents are not the same. The geometric crossover introduced in Maheri and Maheri [7] is used in this study. Utilizing geometric crossover for the problem at hand, the cut-point, a randomly selected real number from the interval of (0,c), divides each parent mechanism (not to be confused with parent chromosome) into two segments. The left segment of the first parent is combined with the right segment of the second parent to form one child. Besides the suitability of geometric crossover for variable length chromosomes, the main advantage of using such a geometric crossover is that the offspring may have different number of panels and hence a topology different from its parents. That is, offspring may have higher or lower number of panels with respect to their parents. Children with larger number of panels are more likely to have better performance in terms of the deviation ε. As a matter of fact, employing a geometric crossover justifies our earlier decision of generating an initial population of accepted solutions rather than feasible solutions, hoping to gain improvement in the deviation ε generation by generation.

After each crossover, the panels to the left of the cut-point of the first parent still map the left segment of the aerofoil, while those panels to the right of thecut-point do not map the right segment of the aerofoil. Therefore, after each crossover, the panel to theleft of the cut-point and all those to its right must be re-synthesized.

Amongst the 3(N-2)+1 genes building a chromosome, (N,xA i,xB i,yB i), the number of precision points N may change through each crossover operation and hence there is no need to be considered forthe mutation. Each one of the remaining design variables x∈{ xAi+1,xBi,yBi } can be selected for mutation. Referring to equations (4) to (7), each design variable is bounded in its corresponding interval of I=(xL,xU). In mutation, a gene x which is randomly selected for mutation will be replaced by a new valuexm, which is randomly chosen from an interval Im⊂I. The subinterval Im shrinks as the generation number increases. This makes the mutation operator dynamic, targeted at avoiding local optimum traps in the early stages of the optimization, and fine tuning, therefore achieving higher precision, at later stages. More details can be found in reference [7]. Selection of a gene for mutation takes place at two steps. First, Pm1 design candidates are randomly selected for mutation and then for each selected design candidate j, Pm2 genes from the set of{ xAi+1,xBi,yBi }; i∈{1,2,…,Nj-2} are selected for an arithmetic mutation. In the earlier generations, where Im has larger values, too many changes applied on too many genes makes the design candidate more vulnerable to becoming an infeasible solution. To avoid this, mutation rate Ps2 varies from small values at the earlier generations to larger values as the number of generation increases. Pm2 can be defined as [7] (16) where Pm2,0 and Pm2, max are the initial and maximummutation rates, respectively,α the level of variability, and fitav and fitmax the average and maximum fitness values of the previous generation, respectively.

After mutation, if the x- or y-coordinate of a B-point is selected for mutation, its corresponding panel mustbe re-synthesized. In the case of selection of the x-coordinate of a point A for mutation, the panel to its left and all those to its right must be re-synthesized.

sec.title: 4 SEQUENTIAL GA
sec.p: In a sequential design, the set of design variablesX={N,xA i,xB i,yB i} is divided into two subsets U={N,xA i} and V={xB i,yB i}. These two subsets will be determined in two steps. In the first step, the mechanism is optimized for the minimum number ofpanels while satisfying the constraint applied onε. This step leads to the determination of U={N,xA i}, the optimal values for the x-coordinates of points A and the number of panels. Having located points A in the first step, in the second step, the corresponding mechanism is designed and optimized for its length, leading to the determination of the rest of design variables, V={xB i,yB i}.

Here, by assuming that the total length of the mechanism is proportional to the number of panels, and therefore to the number of precision points N, the original objective function f (l ) can be replaced with its approximation fapp(N). The original problem is therefore divided into two separate problems as follows:

Step 1: To minimize the number of precision pointsN, subject to constraints (4), (5), and (10). In this problem, the number of precision points is directly treated as a design variable. Knowing the x-coordinates of the leading and trailing edge points, the x-coordinates of N-2 precision points remain to be determined. Total number of design variables and constraints are therefore N-1 and 2(N-2), respectively.

Step 2: To minimize the length of the mechanism l, subject to constraints (6) to (9). Deciding the y-coordinates of points C, and finding their x-coordinates via kinematic constraint, 2(N-2) design variables should be determined subject to 3(N-2) constraints.

sec.title: 4.1 To minimize the number of precision points, N
sec.p: Here, as N is a design variable itself, the chromosomes representing the set of design variables have different lengths. Geometric crossover, explained earlier, can be applied for both constant and variable-length chromosomes. Since a child generated by a geometric crossover can encompass a different number of precision points from those of its parents, there is no need to apply the mutation operation on the number of precision points N. That is, in the algorithm only the design variables x∈{ xAi } (i∈{2,…,Nj-1}) can be selected for mutation.

By defining the fitness based on the number of precision points N only, solutions with the same number of precision points which satisfy constraints (4), (5), and (10) will be assigned the same fitness, regardless of their quality with respect to ε. Considering the facts that ε is actually an objective which is being treated as a constraint, and that the objective function f (l ) has been replaced by its approximated function fapp(N), the assigned fitness to a solution j with Nj precision points is therefore defined as (17) where nN is the number of solutions in the population with the same number of precision points (Nj) and k∈{1,2,…,nN} the rank of a solution in terms of ε within those nN solutions (rank 1 for solution with lowest ε). sec.title: 4.2 To minimize the length of the mechanism
sec.p: After determination of design variables U={N,xA i} in the first step, 2(N-2) design variables V={xB i,yB i} have still to be determined in the second step. In the evaluation of solutions, as constraint (10) is already satisfied in the first step, there is no need to penalize the solutions for the violation of that constraint and therefore the fitness for this step is defined as (18)

Initial population is generated randomly. Using traditional roulette wheel method, the probability of being selected as a parent for crossover is proportional to the fitness of each solution. The same methods of crossover and mutation explained in Section 3 are applied here. Each one of the design variables x∈{xBi,yBi } (i∈{2,…,Nj-1}) can be selected for mutation. After mutation of either of x- or y-coordinate of a point Bi, its corresponding panel must be re-synthesized to find a new valid value for Ci.

sec.title: 5 RESULTS
sec.p: NACA0012 and EPLER 562 have been selected as the initial and target aerofoils respectively. Referring to Fig. 2, other design parameters have been selected as follows: s=0.05, b1=0.1, b2=0.9, δ1=0.01, δ2=0.005, and a=0.01 (dimensions per unit chord length). A goal deviation of ɛg=0.001 and a tolerated deviation of ɛt=2ɛg has been used.

GA parameters used for the hybrid GA-pattern search are as follows: crossover probability Pc=0.8; dynamic mutation parameters as appearing in equation (16): Pm1=0.8, Pm2,0=0.1 and Pm2,max=0.9 and α = 1; total number of generations T=100 and population sizenpop=100.
The pattern search parameters used for the hybrid GA-pattern search are initial grid size Δ0/c=0.08, minimum grid size Δmin/c=0.01, mesh reduction steps = 3, and grid refinement ratio Δk+1/Δk=0.5.
GA parameters for the first step of the sequential GA search are as follows: crossover probability Pc=0.5, mutation probability Pm=0.9, total number of generations T=50, and population size npop=100.
GA parameters for step 2 are as follows: Pc=0.8, Pm1=0.8, Pm2,0=0.1, Pm2,max=0.9, α = 1, T=50, and npop=100.

The search histories of the first and second steps of the run leading to the best solution are shown in Figs 11 to 14. Figure 11 shows the variations of the objective function and the deviation against the number ofgeneration. As expected, the objective function decreases as the number of generations grows. Deviation, however, has a mixed behaviour made up of sharp increases and gradual decreases. This is due to the fact that deviation depends on both the number of precision points and their distribution. A rapid increase in deviation corresponds to a reduction in the number of precision points, while gradual decrease is due to the improvements in the distribution of the precision points. Fig. 11
Search history of the first step of sequential GA: deviation and number of panels of the best individual of each generation

The search history shown in Fig. 12 is rather different from those normally obtained by GAs. Normally, we observe a continuous increase in the maximum fitness with a reducing slope. The slope eventually becomes zero where the algorithm converges (for instance see Fig.9). In contrary to the normal behaviour, here, only rapid increases are observed followed by zero growth over a large number of generations. Such behaviour, in a normal GA, is expected to be vulnerable to premature convergence. However, this is not the case as explained below. The maximum fitness represents the fitness of the best individual in the generation. In view of equation (17), since the best individual also has the first rank (k=1) within all solutions with the same number of precision points, the fitness calculated for the best individual is simply 1/N. This explains the sharp increases and zero growths. Fig. 12
Search history of the first step of sequential GA (fitness defined by equation (17))

Moreover, comparing the average fitness with maximum fitness, it seems that the algorithm has not still converged. Again, this is not the case for this algorithm. As a result of implementing the ranking mechanism in defining the fitness and the fact that two identical solutions will have two consecutive ranks rather than sharing the ranks, two identical solutions will be assigned two different fitnesses. As a result of this, there will always be a gap between the average and the maximum fitnesses, even in the caseof a fully converged algorithm, where all solutions are identical.

sec.title: 6 SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: This study is focused on the design of a mechanism with the function of morphing aerofoil to be used as an active model for testing adaptive surfaces. In the design of this mechanism, it is desired that a certain level of accuracy is achieved in mapping with minimum linkage length.

Since the number of design variables depends on the number of precision points, which is also a design variable, a variable number of design variables are involved. This leads to a rather complicated optimization problem. More importantly, the problem is highly constrained. For highly constrained problems, random generation of initial population can be inefficient and time consuming. In the problem at hand, generating a decent size initial population is a challengeable task. Normally, this can be dealt with by either penalizing the individuals with violated constraint(s) or repairing infeasible solutions. For the problem at hand, since reproduction operators enhance the quality of the initial population in terms of the linkage length and the mapping quality only, initial population must be made of correct mechanisms which satisfy the geometric constraints. This requirement rules out the opportunity of penalizing mechanisms with violated geometric constraints.

In order to circumvent the problem of generating feasible initial population, two approaches were adopted. In the first approach, a hybrid GA-pattern search algorithm was developed. The pattern search was utilized to search for possible feasible solutions in the neighbourhood of an infeasible solution. By employing the pattern search, significant improvement in the efficiency of initial population generation was achieved. In the second approach, the design problem was divided into two smaller design problems of: (a) finding the optimum number and distribution of the precision points and (b) designing the mechanism for minimum linkage length. By employing a sequential GA search, the set of design variables is determined in two consecutive steps. Results of five runs of each search method reveal that while the best solution was produced by the sequential GA search method, hybrid GA-pattern search yielded more consistent results with shorter lengths and better mapping precision in average.

Although the optimization algorithms presented in this article have been developed for the design of a single-DOF kinematic chain, both algorithms can be utilized in the design of other types of mechanisms with the function of mapping, where the number and location of the precision points need to be decided by the designer as part of the optimization process. These algorithms can also be applied to topology optimization of trusses where the number and location of the load-bearing nodes are not known and need to be determined along with other design variables.
